message.content: This question requires knowledge about different types of energy sources and their availability. Options (A), (C), and (D) are considered renewable energy sources because they are constantly replenished naturally. However, option (B) is considered exhaustible because oil is a finite resource that takes millions of years to form and cannot be easily replenished once it is used up. Oil is also considered a non-renewable energy source.

This question requires some knowledge about different energy sources and their availability. Exhaustible resources are those that can be depleted over time. Option (B) oil is considered exhaustible because it is a finite resource that can run out if not properly managed. Options (A) solar, (C) wind, and (D) water are considered renewable resources because they are naturally replenished and can be used indefinitely.

This question requires some basic knowledge about different sources of energy and their availability. Exhaustible resources are those that are finite and can eventually be depleted. Option (B) oil is considered exhaustible because it is a non-renewable resource that is being used up faster than it can be replenished. Option (A) solar is incorrect because solar energy is renewable and comes from the sun, which will continue to provide energy for billions of years. Option (C) wind is also incorrect because wind is a renewable resource that will continue to exist as long as the earth's atmosphere exists. Option (D) water is also incorrect because water, in the form of hydroelectric power, can be harnessed and used as a renewable source of energy.

This question requires knowledge about different types of energy sources and their availability. Options (A), (C), and (D) are considered renewable energy sources because they are naturally replenished. However, option (B), oil, is considered an exhaustible energy source because it is a finite resource that cannot be easily replenished. Oil is formed over millions of years from the remains of ancient plants and animals, and we are using it at a rate much faster than it can be naturally replenished. As a result, oil is not sustainable in the long term and will eventually be depleted.

This question requires knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a non-renewable resource. It takes millions of years to form and once it is extracted and used, it cannot be replaced within a human lifetime. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable resources, meaning they can be replenished within a human lifetime. Solar energy is derived from the sun, which will continue to provide energy for billions of years. Wind is generated by the uneven heating of the earth's surface and will also continue as long as the sun exists. Water is constantly cycling through the earth's hydrologic system and is considered a renewable resource.

This question asks for knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. Option (B) - oil, is considered exhaustible because it is a finite resource that cannot be replenished at the same rate as it is being used. Once oil reserves are depleted, it cannot be replaced. Options (A), (C), and (D) - solar, wind, and water, are considered renewable resources because they can be naturally replenished and are not depleted through use.

This question requires some knowledge about different types of energy sources and their availability. Exhaustible resources are those that can be depleted over time and are not replenished at a fast enough rate. Option (B) oil is considered exhaustible because it is a fossil fuel that takes millions of years to form and cannot be quickly replenished. Options (A) solar, (C) wind, and (D) water are considered renewable resources because they are naturally replenished at a faster rate than they are consumed.

This question requires knowledge about exhaustible and renewable resources. Exhaustible resources are those that can be depleted or used up over time. Oil is an exhaustible resource because it is a finite fossil fuel that is being consumed faster than it is being replenished. Solar energy (A), wind energy (C), and water (D) are considered renewable resources because they are naturally replenished and will not run out in the foreseeable future.

This question requires some basic knowledge about different energy sources and their availability. An exhaustible energy source refers to one that can run out or be depleted over time. Option (B) oil is considered exhaustible because it is a finite resource and can be depleted. Options (A) solar, (C) wind, and (D) water are considered renewable energy sources because they are naturally replenished and can be used indefinitely.

This question requires knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a non-renewable resource, meaning it is finite and will eventually be depleted. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable resources. Solar energy is constantly replenished by the sun, wind energy is generated by the movement of air masses, and water can be replenished through the water cycle.

This question requires some basic knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. Option (B) is correct because oil is a non-renewable resource that is being consumed at a faster rate than it is being replenished. Solar energy (option A) and wind energy (option C) are considered renewable because they rely on natural sources that are constantly replenished. Water (option D) can be both renewable and non-renewable, depending on the specific source.

This question requires some basic knowledge about different sources of energy. An exhaustible resource is one that can be used up or depleted over time. Option (B) states that oil is exhaustible, which is true because it is a non-renewable resource that takes millions of years to form and can be used up faster than it is replenished. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable energy sources that are considered inexhaustible because they are constantly replenished by natural processes.

This question requires knowledge about different types of energy sources and their availability. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a finite resource and will eventually run out. Options (A), (C), and (D) are considered renewable energy sources as they are naturally replenished and not expected to run out in the foreseeable future.

This question requires knowledge about different sources of energy and their availability. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a non-renewable resource that is being consumed at a faster rate than it is being replenished. Eventually, it will run out. It is considered an exhaustible resource. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable resources. Solar energy comes from the sun and will continue to be available as long as the sun exists. Wind energy relies on the movement of air and will continue to be available as long as there are wind patterns. Water, in the form of hydroelectric power, is also a renewable resource as long as there is a constant supply of flowing water.

This question requires knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. "Exhaustible" refers to resources that can be depleted over time. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a non-renewable resource that is being depleted at a faster rate than it is being formed. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable resources, meaning they are inexhaustible and can be replenished naturally.

This question requires some basic knowledge about different types of natural resources. Exhaustible resources are those that can be depleted because they do not renew at the same rate they are consumed. Oil is an exhaustible resource because it takes millions of years to form and we are using it much faster than it can be replenished. Options (A), (C), and (D) are considered renewable resources because they can be replenished naturally over time. Solar energy comes from the sun and will continue to be available as long as the sun exists. Wind energy is created by the movement of air, which is caused by the sun heating the Earth's surface. Water is a renewable resource because it is part of the Earth's water cycle and can be naturally replenished through precipitation.

This question requires knowledge about types of energy sources and whether they can be renewed or not. Option (B) is the correct answer because oil is a non-renewable resource, which means that it will eventually run out. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable sources of energy because they can be replenished naturally. For example, solar energy comes from the sun, wind energy comes from wind, and water energy comes from the water cycle.

This question requires some knowledge about the concept of exhaustible resources. Oil, option (B), is considered to be an exhaustible resource because it is a non-renewable fossil fuel that will eventually run out. Solar, option (A), and wind, option (C), are considered to be renewable resources because they won't run out as long as the sun keeps shining and the wind keeps blowing. Water, option (D), is renewable as well, but it could become scarce in certain areas due to climate change or human activities.

This question requires some knowledge about renewable and non-renewable resources. Oil is a non-renewable resource that is extracted from the ground and will eventually run out. Options (A), (C), and (D) are renewable resources, meaning they can be replenished naturally and do not run out in the same way that non-renewable resources do. Solar energy comes from the sun and will not run out for billions of years. Wind and water can be used to generate energy and will continue to be available as long as we have wind and water.

This question requires knowledge about the different types of energy sources and their sustainability. Oil is an exhaustible resource because it is a non-renewable fossil fuel that is being depleted faster than it can be replaced. Solar, wind, and water are considered renewable energy sources and are not exhaustible because they are replenished naturally and can be used indefinitely.
